comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: What a wonderful picture, though I am more interested in the buildings in the background than the Pomp and Circumstance in the foreground. I wonder if it was taken from the roof of the Customs House or the Thomas Mort building? I have been trying to find out about the "bald-faced building" recently on two State Records NSW photos - www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/3683566752/ and www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/2715092837/ . I thought it was a Fire Station because of the doors, or was it part of the old Sydney Harbour Trust Building? Extraordinary looking. Maybe it was a victim of the 1890's recession, hence the incomplete facade for at least three years.

comment._content: Thank you for pointing out that the Commissariat Store was still there. There was also another tall building at the Quay - from left to right, the Thomas Mort store, then Customs House, then the tallest building on today's Gateway site.
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The Customs House was not tall enough (the two extra floors were added in1896); the "Gateway" warehouse (behind the Paragon Hotel) was at the wrong angle (imho), so I think it was taken from the Mort Store. Easy to see on this contemporary 1895 interactive map - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-rm3443-sd&rgn=0... . Sir Robert Duff became Governor of NSW on 29 May 1893 - is the June date correct for his arrival in the colony? I am also wondering why he arrived at a ferry wharf, and is that him in the carriage near the wharf?

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content:
Thanks beachcomberaustralia!
I took the date from the Australian Encyclopedia and even on the original photograph, it is hard to see the detail but I think he and his wife are in the carriage far right under the gable of the ferry wharf. The ribbon on his chest stands out brightly. We have photographs of other governors arriving at Circular Quay, whereas Royalty arrives in Farm Cove or at the Fleet Steps. Perhaps it depends on whether they arrive on a naval ship or a passenger liner?
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: The convict hulk, Success - as mentioned here - an exhibit ship is also shown in detail in the Library of Congress's Bain Collection. Here's a link: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/tags/success/ Sir Robert Duff arrived in Sydney Harbour aboard the P. and O. company's R.M.S. Parramatta early on Monday 29 May 1893. Sir Robert, aged 57 years, had a grey beard and moustache. He firstly had an unofficial landing at the ground of Government house and then boarded the steamship "Premier" to make his journey to Circular quay for his official landing, depicted above, at Princes Stairs. He landed at about 2.03pm. The scene of his official landing is described in detail on page 5 in the Sydney Morning Herald of the next day: nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13932720 "In the first open carriage Sir Robert, Lady Duff, Miss Duff and Captain the Hon. Rupert Leigh, A.D.C., were seated." The procession went to Government House, where Sir Robert was duly sworn in. So, he certainly was Governor commencing on 29 May, 1893. That is also the date of this photograph. A search in the National Library of Australia's newspaper section of Trove for Princes Stairs Circular Quay yields many trivial results, but also many indicated that Governors and later Governors-General often arrived at the Princes Stairs of Circular Quay. trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/result?q="Princes+stairs&...

comment._content: Great work BobMeade!  I love that full description in the SMH.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
beachcomberaustralia - Thanks.  Trove, and especially the access to early SMH online is proving to be a great tool for investigating these photographs.

One question on my mind is how Princes Stairs got it's name.  

At the moment I suspect something to do with the visit of Prince Alfred.  

We'll see.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I spent a while on Australia Day (26 January) trying to find out about Princes Stairs, and see that Governor Phillip claimed the new colony in 1788 VERY close to where this picture was taken. (And that he was there five days before!). See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia_Day#Arrival_of_the_First_... . Most Prince Alfred 'things' say 'Alfred'. I wonder if the Princes Stairs, like Princes Street (on the ridge of The Rocks, demolished in the 1920s for the Harbour Bridge southern approach) was renamed by Governor Macquarie c.1810 in honour of the Prince Regent (later George IV - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_IV_of_the_United_Kingdom ). See - www.sydneyhistorical.org.au/page3.php?topic=4 . But then the puzzle is that [Semi] Circular Quay was only created in the 1850s (with spoil from the Argyle Cut). Perhaps the place name of Princes Stairs carried over to the new wharf?

comment._content: I love it when my questions are answered by people here on Flickr.  Thanks.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: My particular interest in this picture is that it shows the building from which Arthur Streeton painted Circular Quay the previous year to this photo, in 1892. I think he was in one of the central upstairs windows of the Change Alley 1877 building looking the other way, to the east. I always wondered what the roof in the bottom right corner of the painting was, and this photo shows the store "R.Jackson & J.McMahon - Jewellers"(?), and a recently demolished building between. All gone now for the Cahill Expressway, of course. Also apparent on this photo and the Streeton painting is the row of extremely tall gas (or early electric?) lamps, which might have been a navigation aid for ferries at Circular Quay. Anyone know? Arthur Streeton - "Circular Quay" 1892 (NGA) - artsearch.nga.gov.au/Detail-LRG.cfm?IRN=47963&View=LRG . Also from 1892 - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2376887996/

comment.author: 90719112@N00
comment._content: The Prison Hulk Success, seen in the upper right portion of this wonderful photo, had been on show at the Quay since March. Soon after this photo, she was taken briefly to Newcastle and then Brisbane. You can find more info and photos about this wonderful vessel on my website and blog. Rich Norgard www.shipsuccess.com www.shipsuccess.blogspot.com Success on Facebook: www.facebook.com/pages/Sailing-Ship-Success/1667473400368...

comment.author: 63385174@N06
comment._content: The Princes Steps (or Stairs) were named after Prince Alfred, Duke of Edinburgh, who came ashore there in 1868. The small covered wharf built there took on the name and can be seen at far right in the picture at top. Apart from receiving some dignitaries, it was the base for watermen who provided water taxi services. The wharf was demolished in 1903.
